title: APGAR Score
description: Assesses neonatal vitality at 1 and 5 minutes after birth using 5 clinical criteria

parameters.name: activity_muscle_tone
parameters.description: Assessment of muscle tone and activity

ranges.description: Severe distress - immediate medical attention required
ranges.interpretation: Score 0-3 indicates severe distress. The neonate requires immediate resuscitation and intensive medical intervention. This suggests significant compromise in the transition to extrauterine life.
Score 4-6 indicates moderate distress. The neonate may require some assistance with breathing or circulatory support. Close monitoring and possible intervention are warranted.
Score 7-10 indicates good condition. The neonate is adapting well to extrauterine life. Scores of 8-9 are most common, as most newborns lose 1 point for blue extremities which is normal.

references: Apgar V. A proposal for a new method of evaluation of the newborn infant. Curr Res Anesth Analg. 1953;32(4):260-267.
Apgar V, Holaday DA, James LS, Weisbrot IM, Berrien C. Evaluation of the newborn infant; second report. J Am Med Assoc. 1958;168(15):1985-1988.
American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists Committee on Obstetric Practice. The Apgar Score. Committee Opinion No. 644. Obstet Gynecol. 2015;126:e52-55.
formula: Sum of 5 components: Activity (0-2) + Pulse (0-2) + Grimace (0-2) + Appearance (0-2) + Respirations (0-2) = Total Score (0-10)
notes: The APGAR score should be assessed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth
If the 5-minute score is <7, additional scores should be assessed every 5 minutes up to 20 minutes
The score should not be used to predict long-term neurological outcomes
A score of 10 is very unusual as most newborns lose 1 point for blue extremities
Created by Dr. Virginia Apgar in 1952 at Columbia University
